ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD HOUSING ESTATES
(Organisation of residents' associations)


    1. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Defence to what extent the People's Association has encouraged the organisation of residents' associations in Housing and Development Board housing estates.

    The Minister for Defence (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, organising residents' associations in Housing and Development Board housing estates is not a function of the People's Association whose main objective is the organisation and development of community centres in all the constituencies in the Republic. The People's Association, in

Column: 429

liaison with the management committees of the various community centres, initiates and supervises the activities in the centres. However, where residents in Housing and Development Board estates have problems to raise with the Housing and Development Board authorities, they can make representations through the Citizens' Consultative Committee in their estates. Incidentally, the Citizens' Consultative Committees come under the portfolio of the Prime Minister.

    Up to now, there has been close and successful liaison through the C.C.C, between the Housing and Development Board and residents in the following estates, namely, Henderson Road, Bukit Merah, Toa Payoh, Kallang, Kampong Java and Tiong Bahru estates.

PEOPLE'S ASSOCIATION'S
KINDERGARTEN CLASSES
(Particulars)


    2. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Defence (a) what has been the total enrolment for 1968 in the kindergarten classes run by the People's Association; (b) what are the media of instruction: and (c) whether he is satisfied with the progress made.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, when the People's Association first organised kindergarten classes in community cen tres in January 1964, there were only eight centres providing this service. However, by the end of 1968, 138 community centres were conducting kindergarten classes and 390 such classes were organised with a total enrolment of 11,190 children. Of the 390 classes, 15 of them with a student population of 445 are taught in Malay. 35 with a student population of 1.125 in English and the rest in Mandarin, i.e.. 339 classes with 9,620 children.

    Notwithstanding the above classification, Mr Speaker, Sir, a second language is also taught in all classes once a week.

    Satisfactory progress has been made by the People's Association in the or~anisation of kindergarten classes as a service to the community. Furthermore,

Column: 430

the standard of instruction provided in these classes is comparable to that of other kindergarten classes in the Republic.

SINGAPORE CITIZENS IN
MALAYSIAN ARMED FORCES
(Applications for transfer to Singapore Armed Forces)


    3. Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi asked the Minister for Defence (a) how many Singapore Citizens had enlisted in the Malaysian Armed Forces during the time when Singapore was in Malaysia: and (b) how many of them have applied to the Ministry of the Interior and Defence for transfer to the Singapore Armed Forces.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I cannot answer the first part of the question because we do not have figures showing how many Singapore citizens are serving in the Malaysian Armed Forces. The records are with them.

    As for the second part of the question, to date there have been 46 applications for transfer to the Singapore Armed Forces from Singapore citizens who were enlisted as members of the Malaysian Armed Forces outside Singapore.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Sir, can the Minister say how many Singapore citizens have been transferred to the Singapore Armed Forces?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, out of the 46. 21 were rejected on grounds of unsuitable vocation, had record or due to lack of proof of citizenship.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Government accept the transfer of Singapore citizens now in the Malaysian Armed Forces into the Republic's Armed Forces with no loss in seniority or status?

    Mr Lim Kim San: I cannot give an assurance that there will be no loss in seniority or status, because the training and the service that is required by us might be different from what the man has been accustomed to.

Column: 431



    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Sir, can the Minister say what is the official attitude of the Government towards Singapore citizens serving in foreign armed forces including the Malaysian Armed Forces?

    Mr Speaker: That is not a supplementary question which properly arises out of the original question.

    Mr Lim Kim San: I say good luck and all the best to them.

TEENAGE NEWS-VENDORS
(Prevention of practice of selling newspapers at major road junctions)


    4. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Defence whether he proposes to take steps to prevent teenage children from selling evening newspapers carrying results of big sweep draws (Mahpiewpo) at major road junctions as this practice not only causes danger to the children themselves, but also impedes the flow of vehicular traffic.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the police has taken action to prevent teenagers from selling Mahpiewpo at busy traffic junctions and at known places where they congregate. I think there have been less of them, but we would like to prevent them altogether. I can assure the Member for Mountbatten that action has been taken and will be taken to see that these people do not hold up traffic unnecessarily and, at the same time, endanger their lives.

(Police station)

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, there is a proposal to build a police station at Toa Payoh for which there is provision in the 1969 Estimates. A 3½ acre site has been selected in Toa Payoh Housing

Column: 432

Estate. It has got to be acquired and alt I can say is that this project is still under consideration by my Ministry.

CRIMINAL LAW (TEMPORARY PROVISIONS) ORDINANCE, 1955
(Particulars of prosecutions and convictions)


    6. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Defence (a) how many persons who were arrested for detention under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance, 1955, were thereafter soon charged and prosecuted in court during the period 1st January, 1967, to 30th June, 1968; (b) how many of such prosecutions resulted in convictions; and (c) how many of such convictions were the result of the accused pleading guilty.

    The Minister of State for Defence (Mr Wee Toon Boon) (for the Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance, 1955, a total of 1,408 persons were arrested during the period 1st January, 1967, to 30th June, 1968. Of this number, 438 persons were charged and prosecuted in court. Four hundred and twenty six such prosecutions resulted in convictions and 396 of such convictions were the result of the accused pleading guilty.

SOCIAL ESCORT SERVICES


    7. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Defence whether the Police have deemed it necessary to look into the matter of the growing number of' agencies offering social escort services in Singapore; and whether he considers any' legislation necessary in this regard.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, the police are always looking into illegal activities. I do not know whether tourist agencies are largely engaged in illegal activities, but the police have kept an eye on them and, up to date, my information is that they suspect hat some of them are up to no good. There are 106 of these firms registered and where they are suspected of carrying on activities which the

Column: 433

Member for Katong has in mind, the Anti-Vice Branch will take appropriate action.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Sir, I had in mind the regulations administered by the Tourist Promotion Board. If I may just quote from the Tourist Promotion (Certification and Control of Guides) Regulations, 1964:

    'No person, other than a person whose name is on the Register and who has been issued a letter of authority under the provisions of sub-paragraph (b) of paragraph (1) of regulation 7 of these Regulations, shall be entitled to act as a tourist guide for remuneration:'.

If I may just add, Sir, many of these escort services purport to offer tourist services and, as such, they may be infringing the Regulations. Will the Minister consider taking action if there is infringement of these Regulations?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, I have never made use of this escort service. Personally, I cannot say that I am aware of this state of affairs. But where there is an infringement of the Regulations, I can assure Members that the police will take appropriate action.

SINGAPORE ARTS COUNCIL BUILDING FUND AND
CONSTRUCTION OF NATIONAL ART GALLERY AND
ACADEMY OF ARTS BUILDING


    8. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Culture (a) what is the total amount of donations by members of the public to the Singapore Arts Council Building Fund up to 31st October, 1968; and (b) when the construction of the National Art Gallery and the Academy of Arts building will commence.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Mr Fong Sip Chee) (for the Minister for Culture): Mr Speaker, Sir, the total amount of donations by members of the public to the Singapore Arts Council Fund, together with accrued interest up to 31st October this year, is $1,135,809.60 cents.

Column: 434



    With regard to the second part of the question, the National Art Gallery and the Academy of Arts project is one of the projects of the Singapore Arts Council, which is a registered society. It is for the Singapore Arts Council to determine the schedule of construction of the building. This will depend both on preparations for specifications based on a study of the actual requirements in detail as well as availability of further funds both for the capital as well as for the running costs.

NATIONAL LIBRARY
(Professional and non-professional staff)


    9. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Culture (a) by what standards does the National Library decide on the proportion of professional and non- professional staff; and (b) why do some professional staff in the National Library have to spend much time in non-professional work, such as stamping, issuing and shelving books, and whether steps will be taken to remedy the situation.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee (for the Minister for Culture): Mr Speaker, Sir, in developed countries, the proportion of professional staff to non-professional staff is usually one to three, excluding manual staff. The National Library at present has a total establishment of 142 staff, excluding daily-rated staff. Out of this total, 45 are professional staff, including 25 who are qualified librarians.

    Although the present proportion of professional staff to non-professional staff in the National Library closely approximates that of more developed countries, libraries in these countries have a very high degree of mechanisation of library routines. The National Library is, therefore, working towards achieving a higher proportion of non-professional staff, i.e., to have one-fourth instead of one-third professional staff in order that the non-professional duties may be carried out entirely by non-professional staff.

Officers who have acquired professional qualifications receive two additional increments and are eligible for promotion posts.

    The total number of posts in the library service is now 56, including 11. Of this number , one was an American who returned

Column: 436

One left for Britain on marriage, one was a Malaysian citizen who took up a post in Malaysia, six took up posts in other libraries in the Republic, one took up a teaching post and one was a married woman who resigned in order that she can take care of her family affairs.

    In addition, the National Library had two more officers whose qualifications were not recognised and who resigned to take up appointments in other Singapore libraries.

    No officer left the National Library on transfer. The National Library service is part of a unified library service and officers may be required to serve in the National Library or in other Government departments.

    The total number of posts in the library service is now 56, including 11 now serving in other Government departments.

NATIONAL LIBRARY
(Statistics of members and books purchased)


    11. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Culture (a) if he will give the numbers of members of the National Library grouped according to their interest in Malay, Chinese. Tamil or English material as at 15th November.1968; and (b) how many books, giving separate figures for Malay, Chinese, Tamil and English books, have been purchased by the Library between 1st January, 1967, and 15th November, 1968.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee (for the Minister for Culture): Sir, it is not possible for us to give the number of members of the National Library as requested in the question, because many readers borrow hooks in more than one language. An indication of the interest in Malay, Chinese, Tamil or English material can be obtained from the figures for the number of books borrowed in these languages.

    However, as the National Library has lent over one million books a year since 1966, statistics of the breakdown of the

number of books borrowed in the four languages are kept only for the Library Extension Section, that is to say, the two part-time branches and the mobile library points. In 1967, out of a total of 268.626 books borrowed by some 24,660 members of the Library Extension Section, 63,249 were Malay, 56,006 were Chinese, 8,091 were Tamil and 141,280 were English. From January to October 1968, the total number of books borrowed by some 28,000 members of the Library Extension Section was 213,455, of which 39,923 were Malay, 50,746 were Chinese, 8,166 were Tamil and 114,620 were English.

BRANCH LIBRARY IN
QUEENSTOWN
(Air-conditioning)


    12. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Culture whether the National Library will be entirely air-conditioned and whether the branch Library in Queenstown will also eventually be air-conditioned.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Inche Sha'ari Bin Tadin) (for the Minister for Culture): Mr Speaker, Sir, a sum of $51,750 is being provided in draft in the 1969 Development Estimates for air-conditioning of those areas in the National Library which are presently not air conditioned. For the information of the Member for Serangoon Gardens, provision has also been made in the building

plan for the eventual air-conditioning of Queenstown Branch Library.

TELEVISION SINGAPURA
(Telecasting of student debates in Malay, Tamil and English)


    13. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Culture whether TV Singapura has any plans to organise and telecast debates in Malay, Tamil and English by students.

    Inche Sha'ari Bin Tadin (for the Minister for Culture): Mr Speaker, Sir, the short answer to the Member for Sembawang is "Yes". A very successful series of debates have been organised for students from the secondary and college levels in the Chinese language stream. These debates have also been edited and will be published in booklet form very soon.

    Plans have been finalised to organise and telecast similar debates in the English language stream in the first quarter of 1969. It is anticipated that response from the English language stream, both in quality and quantity, will be as good as that from the Chinese language stream.

    Active consideration is now being given by TV Singapura to organise similar debates in the Malay and Tamil language streams and, subject to factors such as availability of talent, broadcasting resources, etc., it is hoped that similar debates in Malay and Tamil can be organised and telecast after the debates in English.

Column: 438

SINGAPORE
(Plans for commemoration of 150th anniversary)


    14. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Culture (a) whether exhaustive plans are being worked out to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the founding of Singapore next year; and (b) whether such plans will be coordinated with the industrial and commercial sectors so as to achieve the maximum world-wide publicity of the event.

Column: 439



    Inche Sha'ari Bin Tadin (for the Minister for Culture): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is "Yes". Plans have been worked out to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the founding of Singapore next year.

    The answer to the second question is also "Yes". Such plans will be coordinated with the industrial and commercial sectors and, when finalised, will be locally and internationally publicised. The programmes will be a national effort spread over a period of time with a wide cross-section of institutions and individuals in the public and private sectors involved. The whole object of the celebration will be to evoke emotional and permanent responses of patriotism in the people. The emphasis will be on youth drawing inspiration from the past in the development of this vibrant society and dedicating themselves to the future with confidence and resolve.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten): Sir, will the Parliamentary Secretary indicate when these nation- wide celebrations will be held and whether it is possible that this 150th anniversary can be held in conjunction with the National Day celebrations?

    Inche Sha'ari Bin Tadin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the 150th anniversary will be celebrated on a nation-wide basis and will be spread over next year, though officially sponsored events will be concentrated: during the period June to September 1969. It is expected that cultural and other organisations will organise their own activities in different parts of Singapore and all forms of celebrations, including those held indi vidually or collectively by constituencies, will be encouraged.

    The Chairman: Amendment (12), Mr Rodrigo.

    Mr L. P. Rodrigo (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday I was engaged in the topic of principals of schools before we were terrorised by the Environmental Public Health Bill. I was calling upon the principals of schools to make their contribution to education in a form beyond their administrative duties as heads of schools. I was calling upon them to apply their minds to problems in education relevant to the times and, especially,. relevant perhaps to their respective localities and schools and to put this thinking on paper for submission to the Ministry of Education and also to be published and sorted out for the benefit of the teaching profession.

    Sir, the heads of schools, having stored up that much experience and ability to merit their appointments as heads of schools by the Public Service Commission, should gladly undertake these duties without insistence on the part of the Ministry, and I certainly would look forward to such responses from principals of schools. But they also have hard times these days.

    I would like to refer the Minister to the last appointment of principals of primary schools. I do not know whether this may be within the ambit of the Public Service Commission. If it is, the Minister can still do something to remedy what I think is an undesirable situation. The appointment of the princi pals of primary schools was last made on the basis of a circular to the schools calling for applications for this appointment and the indication was that the

Column: 441

appointment was meant to be a substantive appointment. A number of applications were made. Subsequent interviews followed, and then short-listing, and eventually the appointment was made in two categories. One was a category of appointees who were appointed substantively with the usual probationary period.

3.00 p.m.

    The other category was a category of appointees who were informed that they were rejected for the substantive appointments but that they were to be appointed in an acting capacity until one year from the date of the appointment or until the incumbent for the post arrived. This would mean that this second category of appointees would revert to teaching and they would suffer some embarrassment.

    But what is alarming is that when some of these appointees approached the officials in the Ministry and indicated that this was something for which they had not bargained, and when they asked whether they could refuse the second type of appointment, it appeared that they were informed that they could, provided they signed certain documents to the effect that they reject the appointment on condition that they are prepared to forfeit promotional opportunities which may come their way in the future. If this is so, I think this is a very iniquitous practice on the part of the Ministry, it is unfair to these applicants. It is just like inviting a guest to your house for a cocktail party and as soon as he gets into your house, you grab him by the scruff of his neck and drag him to the backyard to clean up the mess, perhaps in preparation for the "Keep Singapore Clean" campaign! And when he protests, you threaten to blow off his brains with a blunderbuss. I think this situation ought to be resolved somehow or other, because I understand that they have been informed by the Ministry that their appointments would proceed until further notice - in other words, until a further one year from the date on which they were last notified or until the incumbent came along to displace them.

Column: 442



    I hope the Minister will look into this situation with a view to remedying an undesirable situation.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, prior to the setting up of the Harvey Salaries Commission by our Government, the Ministry of Education administered numerous salary scales for various categories of teachers with resultant anomalies and injustices. It was hoped by all that with the publication of the findings of the Commission, comprehensive and effective measures would be adopted to do away with, once and for all, the innumerable ramifications of the prevailing anomalies and that a unified salary structure would be drawn up. It is true that some anomalies have been rectified, but the overall position in the Ministry of Education remains as unsatisfactory as before.

    There were a number of issues which were considered not only by the unions representing the employees but also the Ministry of Education and: the Treasury to be in dire need of an equitable rectification. But the Harvey Commission appeared to have overlooked the representations made by the Ministry of Education as well as by the unions representing the teachers. I am sure it is not too late to rectify the anomalies since both parties - the Ministry of Education and the unions representing the teachers - agree that there is a need for rectification.

    In particular, there are two outstanding issues that should be resolved without any further delay: one, remuneration to the senior assistants and two, salary scales for promotion posts in the Ministry of Education.

    Sir, in the 1950's, all schools that operated two sessions had one principal for each session. However, with the intensification of the school-building programme, the shortage of senior and experienced teachers for promotion as principals became so acute that, as a temporary measure, the practice of appointing one principal for both morning and afternoon sessions was adopted. Unfortunately, this temporary measure

Column: 443

became, with the passage of time, a permanent policy of the Ministry of Education and, at the moment, there is only one principal for both the morning and afternoon sessions. Where principals cannot be present throughout the whole of the afternoon session, senior assistants are then appointed to manage the school for and on behalf of the principals. These senior assistants are not given additional remuneration although they are made to shoulder additional responsibilities. After repeated representations by the unions, the Ministry of Education agreed with the unions that it was an inequitable situation which had to be rectified and that a recommendation to this effect would be made by the Ministry to the Harvey Salaries Commission. But it appears that the Harvey Salaries Commission has not given any consideration to this recommendation made by both the unions and the Ministry.

    The Ministry of Education is the only Government department where promotion posts do not carry different salary scales but only allowances. This practice is still continuing in spite of the fact that the Ministry of Education as well as the unions have agreed on numerous occasions that it creates injustices in many ways.

    In view of the circumstances which I have just set out, I hope the Minister for Education will take the necessary action to remove these anomalies by entering into negotiations with the unions in order to bring about an amicable and equitable settlement of the issues.

    As a matter of fact, the Harvey Salaries Commission has recommended in paragraph 198 of its Report that the structure and reorganisation of the Ministry of Education must be looked into.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, may I, at the same time, congratulate the Ministry of Education on being far- sighted and willing to rectify mistakes made by the Harvey Salaries Comniission. I refer to a newspaper report yesterday that the

Column: 444

Ministry of Education had entered into negotiations with the Malay Teachers' Union on the unduly and unreasonably depressed salary scales recommended by the Harvey Salaries Commission for religious teachers in Singapore. Sir, we recognise that no one, not even a commission of eminent persons, is infallible. It is quite obvious that the Harvey Salaries Commission has, unintentionally or unwittingly, made some recommendations which are not in keeping with the aspirations of our Republic and or with the recommendations of the various Government departments and the employees' unions.

    It is commendable that the Government has accepted the Commission's recommendations with some modifica tions. There is scope for further adjustments of the recommendations as the negotiations going on at the moment between the Ministry of Education and the Malay Teachers' Union clearly indicate.

    May I enquire from the Minister if further negotiations will be conducted between the Ministry of Education and other categories of teachers on similar findings of the Commission which do not appear to have taken into adequate consideration the recommendations made by the Government, as well as by the employees' unions? Sir, in the private sector, if both the employers' and employees' unions agree that a certain category of posts can and should be considered as promotion posts, the resultant negotiations conducted by the parties involved are confined to the quantum of remuneration for the pro motion posts. In other words, the dispute centres on the fair and equitable remuneration that is payable to the holders of the promotion posts. The terms of the negotiated settlement are then incorporated into a collective agreement which sets out the salary scales for such posts and it is duly certified and registered by the Industrial Arbitration Court~ In the Ministry of Education, there are two issues which merit similar treatment and yet the
